events.text_segment:
About three o’clock the quality of Wilson’s incoherent muttering changed—he grew quieter and began to talk about the yellow car. He announced that he had a way of finding out whom the yellow car belonged to, and then he blurted out that a couple of months ago his wife had come from the city with her face bruised and her nose swollen.
But when he heard himself say this, he flinched and began to cry “Oh, my God!” again in his groaning voice. Michaelis made a clumsy attempt to distract him.
“How long have you been married, George? Come on there, try and sit still a minute, and answer my question. How long have you been married?”
“Twelve years.”
“Ever had any children? Come on, George, sit still—I asked you a question. Did you ever have any children?”
The hard brown beetles kept thudding against the dull light, and whenever Michaelis heard a car go tearing along the road outside it sounded to him like the car that hadn’t stopped a few hours before. He didn’t like to go into the garage, because the work bench was stained where the body had been lying, so he moved uncomfortably around the office—he knew every object in it before morning—and from time to time sat down beside Wilson trying to keep him more quiet.
“Have you got a church you go to sometimes, George? Maybe even if you haven’t been there for a long time? Maybe I could call up the church and get a priest to come over and he could talk to you, see?”
“Don’t belong to any.”
“You ought to have a church, George, for times like this. You must have gone to church once. Didn’t you get married in a church? Listen, George, listen to me. Didn’t you get married in a church?”
“That was a long time ago.”
The effort of answering broke the rhythm of his rocking—for a moment he was silent. Then the same half-knowing, half-bewildered look came back into his faded eyes.
“Look in the drawer there,” he said, pointing at the desk.
“Which drawer?”
“That drawer—that one.”
Michaelis opened the drawer nearest his hand. There was nothing in it but a small, expensive dog-leash, made of leather and braided silver. It was apparently new.
“This?” he inquired, holding it up.
Wilson stared and nodded.
“I found it yesterday afternoon. She tried to tell me about it, but I knew it was something funny.”
“You mean your wife bought it?”
“She had it wrapped in tissue paper on her bureau.”
Michaelis didn’t see anything odd in that, and he gave Wilson a dozen reasons why his wife might have bought the dog-leash. But conceivably Wilson had heard some of these same explanations before, from Myrtle, because he began saying “Oh, my God!” again in a whisper—his comforter left several explanations in the air.
“Then he killed her,” said Wilson. His mouth dropped open suddenly.
“Who did?”
“I have a way of finding out.”
“You’re morbid, George,” said his friend. “This has been a strain to you and you don’t know what you’re saying. You’d better try and sit quiet till morning.”
“He murdered her.”
“It was an accident, George.”
Wilson shook his head. His eyes narrowed and his mouth widened slightly with the ghost of a superior “Hm!”
“I know,” he said definitely. “I’m one of these trusting fellas and I don’t think any harm to nobody, but when I get to know a thing I know it. It was the man in that car. She ran out to speak to him and he wouldn’t stop.”
Michaelis had seen this too, but it hadn’t occurred to him that there was any special significance in it. He believed that Mrs. Wilson had been running away from her husband, rather than trying to stop any particular car.
“How could she of been like that?”
“She’s a deep one,” said Wilson, as if that answered the question. “Ah-h-h—”
He began to rock again, and Michaelis stood twisting the leash in his hand.
“Maybe you got some friend that I could telephone for, George?”
This was a forlorn hope—he was almost sure that Wilson had no friend: there was not enough of him for his wife. He was glad a little later when he noticed a change in the room, a blue quickening by the window, and realized that dawn wasn’t far off. About five o’clock it was blue enough outside to snap off the light.
Wilson’s glazed eyes turned out to the ash-heaps, where small grey clouds took on fantastic shapes and scurried here and there in the faint dawn wind.
“I spoke to her,” he muttered, after a long silence. “I told her she might fool me but she couldn’t fool God. I took her to the window”—with an effort he got up and walked to the rear window and leaned with his face pressed against it—“and I said ‘God knows what you’ve been doing, everything you’ve been doing. You may fool me, but you can’t fool God!’ ”
Standing behind him, Michaelis saw with a shock that he was looking at the eyes of Doctor T. J. Eckleburg, which had just emerged, pale and enormous, from the dissolving night.
“God sees everything,” repeated Wilson.
“That’s an advertisement,” Michaelis assured him. Something made him turn away from the window and look back into the room. But Wilson stood there a long time, his face close to the window pane, nodding into the twilight.

He seemed to be recalling something, his voice dropping to a whisper as he muttered about the car that had brought tragedy into his life. The yellow car, a symbol of wealth and carelessness, had become a haunting memory for Wilson. As he spoke, his words were fragmented, filled with a mixture of anger and despair. Daisy's voice echoed in his mind, her laughter and her careless driving, which had ultimately led to the death of Myrtle.

Wilson's hands trembled as he remembered the day of the accident. He had been working in his garage, the scent of oil and gasoline thick in the air, when he saw the yellow car speed past. The car's sleek body and bright color had always caught his eye, but now it seemed to mock him, a reminder of the night that changed everything. He had run outside, shouting for the car to stop, but it was too late. Myrtle had been hit, and the driver had vanished into the night.

The memory of that evening was etched deeply into Wilson's mind. He saw the scene over and over again—the flashing headlights, Myrtle's scream, the terrible impact. His grief and rage had grown since that day, fueling his obsession with finding the owner of the yellow car. He believed that the man who owned it was responsible for Myrtle's death, and he was determined to confront him.

As Wilson continued to mutter about the yellow car, his voice grew more distant, as if he was reliving the moment. The world around him seemed to fade away, leaving only the image of the car and the tragedy it had brought. His mind was consumed with thoughts of justice, of holding the guilty party accountable.

Meanwhile, the atmosphere in the room was tense. Tom Buchanan, who had been listening quietly, now looked uneasy. He knew that Wilson's fixation on the yellow car was dangerous, and he feared that the situation might escalate. Daisy, sitting nearby, appeared distressed, her face pale and her hands trembling.

Nick Carraway observed the scene with a mixture of pity and concern. He understood Wilson's pain, but he also recognized the potential for violence. The tragic events had set in motion a chain of reactions that could not be undone. The yellow car, once a symbol of luxury and leisure, had become a catalyst for destruction.

As the afternoon wore on, Wilson's muttering grew more frantic. He seemed to be pleading with himself, trying to make sense of the chaos. His eyes darted around the room, searching for something, perhaps the owner of the yellow car or a sign of justice.

Gatsby, who had been quietly observing, finally spoke. His voice was calm but firm. "Wilson, I understand your pain, but violence won't bring Myrtle back. We need to find the truth and face it."

Wilson looked at Gatsby, his eyes filled with a mixture of anger and sorrow. For a moment, he seemed to consider Gatsby's words, but then he shook his head, as if rejecting the idea of peace. His mind was too consumed with grief and rage.

The room fell into a heavy silence, broken only by Wilson's continued muttering. Outside, the sun was beginning to set, casting long shadows across the room. The yellow car, a silent witness to the tragedy, remained a symbol of the reckless indifference that had led to so much suffering.

In the days that followed, the community grappled with the aftermath of the accident. Wilson's obsession with the yellow car grew, and he became more isolated, his grief turning into a dangerous obsession. The police investigation revealed little, and the owner of the car remained elusive.

Daisy, haunted by guilt and fear, withdrew from her social circle. She knew that her careless actions had set these events in motion, but she was powerless to change the past. Gatsby continued to dream of a future that could never be, holding onto hope despite the tragedy.

The yellow car, once a symbol of glamour, now represented the destructive power of wealth and privilege. It was a reminder of how the pursuit of happiness and success could lead to ruin when moral boundaries were ignored.

As the story of Gatsby and Wilson unfolded, it became clear that the American Dream was a fragile illusion, built on illusions and superficial appearances. The characters' lives were intertwined by their desires, their secrets, and their tragic flaws.

In the end, the yellow car was not just a vehicle but a metaphor for the recklessness and moral decay that permeated the society. It carried the weight of guilt, loss, and the inevitable consequences of a world obsessed with materialism.

Wilson's muttering about the yellow car was a lament for innocence lost and justice denied. It was a cry of despair from a man who had been broken by the relentless pursuit of happiness in a world that valued appearances over truth.

As the novel concludes, the characters are left to grapple with the aftermath of their choices, haunted by the ghosts of the past and the elusive promise of the American Dream. The yellow car remains a silent witness to the tragedy, a symbol of the destructive power of wealth and the fragility of human morality.

events.title: Wilson's Disappearance, Search, and Gatsby's Final Swim
detailed_summary: By six a.m., Michaelis is exhausted; another man arrives, and they eat breakfast while Wilson is quieter.
Michaelis goes home to sleep.
When Michaelis returns four hours later, Wilson is gone.
Wilson's movements are traced on foot through Port Roosevelt and Gad's Hill, where he bought food he didn't eat.
Witnesses report seeing a man acting strangely.
He disappears for three hours; police assume he was searching garages for the yellow car, based on his statement to Michaelis.
However, no garage attendant confirms seeing him, suggesting he found the information another way.
By half-past two, Wilson is in West Egg asking for directions to Gatsby's house, indicating he now knows Gatsby's name.
Around the same time (two o'clock), Gatsby decides to go for a swim and tells the butler to bring any phone messages to the pool.
He gets the pneumatic mattress from the garage, with the chauffeur helping inflate it.
Gatsby instructs that his main car (the one involved in the accident) not be taken out, despite needing fender repair.
He carries the mattress towards the pool alone, disappearing among the trees.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: By six o’clock Michaelis was worn out, and grateful for the sound of a car stopping outside.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Once he stopped and shifted it a little, and the chauffeur asked him if he needed help, but he shook his head and in a moment disappeared among the yellowing trees.

events.text_segment:
By six o’clock Michaelis was worn out, and grateful for the sound of a car stopping outside. It was one of the watchers of the night before who had promised to come back, so he cooked breakfast for three, which he and the other man ate together. Wilson was quieter now, and Michaelis went home to sleep; when he awoke four hours later and hurried back to the garage, Wilson was gone.
His movements—he was on foot all the time—were afterward traced to Port Roosevelt and then to Gad’s Hill, where he bought a sandwich that he didn’t eat, and a cup of coffee. He must have been tired and walking slowly, for he didn’t reach Gad’s Hill until noon. Thus far there was no difficulty in accounting for his time—there were boys who had seen a man “acting sort of crazy,” and motorists at whom he stared oddly from the side of the road. Then for three hours he disappeared from view. The police, on the strength of what he said to Michaelis, that he “had a way of finding out,” supposed that he spent that time going from garage to garage thereabout, inquiring for a yellow car. On the other hand, no garage man who had seen him ever came forward, and perhaps he had an easier, surer way of finding out what he wanted to know. By half-past two he was in West Egg, where he asked someone the way to Gatsby’s house. So by that time he knew Gatsby’s name.
At two o’clock Gatsby put on his bathing-suit and left word with the butler that if anyone phoned word was to be brought to him at the pool. He stopped at the garage for a pneumatic mattress that had amused his guests during the summer, and the chauffeur helped him to pump it up. Then he gave instructions that the open car wasn’t to be taken out under any circumstances—and this was strange, because the front right fender needed repair.
Gatsby shouldered the mattress and started for the pool. Once he stopped and shifted it a little, and the chauffeur asked him if he needed help, but he shook his head and in a moment disappeared among the yellowing trees.

- The completion summarizes Gatsby's disappearance as "disappeared among the foliage," which is less specific than the original's reference to the yellowing trees.

Overall, the completion would benefit from more precise attention to the sequence of actions, inclusion of specific time references, and retention of contextual details that add depth to the narrative.

As dawn approached, the city would wake up to a new day, but for those involved, the scars of that night would linger, shaping their lives in ways they could not yet understand.

events.title: The Holocaust: Gatsby's Death and Wilson's Suicide
detailed_summary: No phone call comes for Gatsby; the butler waits until four o'clock.
Nick speculates Gatsby no longer expected the call or cared, having perhaps realized his dream was lost and the real world felt alien and grotesque.
He imagines Gatsby perceiving the world as 'material without being real,' filled with 'poor ghosts,' anticipating the 'ashen, fantastic figure' (Wilson) approaching.
The chauffeur hears shots but doesn't initially react.
Nick arrives from the station, his anxious rush up the steps alarming the staff, who Nick believes already suspected the worst.
Nick, the chauffeur, butler, and gardener hurry to the pool.
They find Gatsby's body on the mattress, drifting irregularly in the pool.
A small gust of wind and leaves disturb the mattress's course, tracing a thin red circle in the water from his blood.
As they carry Gatsby's body towards the house, the gardener discovers Wilson's body nearby in the grass.
The murder-suicide is complete.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: No telephone message arrived, but the butler went without his sleep and waited for it until four o’clock—until long after there was anyone to give it to if it came.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It was after we started with Gatsby toward the house that the gardener saw Wilson’s body a little way off in the grass, and the holocaust was complete.

events.text_segment:
No telephone message arrived, but the butler went without his sleep and waited for it until four o’clock—until long after there was anyone to give it to if it came. I have an idea that Gatsby himself didn’t believe it would come, and perhaps he no longer cared. If that was true he must have felt that he had lost the old warm world, paid a high price for living too long with a single dream. He must have looked up at an unfamiliar sky through frightening leaves and shivered as he found what a grotesque thing a rose is and how raw the sunlight was upon the scarcely created grass. A new world, material without being real, where poor ghosts, breathing dreams like air, drifted fortuitously about… like that ashen, fantastic figure gliding toward him through the amorphous trees.
The chauffeur—he was one of Wolfshiem’s protégés—heard the shots—afterwards he could only say that he hadn’t thought anything much about them. I drove from the station directly to Gatsby’s house and my rushing anxiously up the front steps was the first thing that alarmed anyone. But they knew then, I firmly believe. With scarcely a word said, four of us, the chauffeur, butler, gardener, and I hurried down to the pool.
There was a faint, barely perceptible movement of the water as the fresh flow from one end urged its way toward the drain at the other. With little ripples that were hardly the shadows of waves, the laden mattress moved irregularly down the pool. A small gust of wind that scarcely corrugated the surface was enough to disturb its accidental course with its accidental burden. The touch of a cluster of leaves revolved it slowly, tracing, like the leg of transit, a thin red circle in the water.
It was after we started with Gatsby toward the house that the gardener saw Wilson’s body a little way off in the grass, and the holocaust was complete.

events.title: Investigation, Isolation, and Failed Contact
detailed_summary: The days following Gatsby's death are chaotic, filled with police, media, and onlookers.
A detective labels Wilson a 'madman', setting the tone for inaccurate newspaper reports.
Catherine lies at the inquest, claiming Myrtle was happy with Wilson and never knew Gatsby, effectively simplifying the case to murder-suicide driven by grief.
Catherine's performance convinces the authorities and she portrays herself as deeply mourning her sister.
Nick finds himself aligned with the deceased Gatsby and feels isolated as the sole person truly interested in him.
All inquiries about Gatsby are directed to Nick, solidifying his sense of responsibility.
Nick instinctively calls Daisy shortly after finding Gatsby's body, only to learn she and Tom have left town without a forwarding address or return date.
The Buchanans' departure leaves Nick unable to reach them.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: After two years I remember the rest of that day, and that night and the next day, only as an endless drill of police and photographers and newspaper men in and out of Gatsby’s front door.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Can’t say.”

events.text_segment:
After two years I remember the rest of that day, and that night and the next day, only as an endless drill of police and photographers and newspaper men in and out of Gatsby’s front door. A rope stretched across the main gate and a policeman by it kept out the curious, but little boys soon discovered that they could enter through my yard, and there were always a few of them clustered open-mouthed about the pool. Someone with a positive manner, perhaps a detective, used the expression “madman” as he bent over Wilson’s body that afternoon, and the adventitious authority of his voice set the key for the newspaper reports next morning.
Most of those reports were a nightmare—grotesque, circumstantial, eager, and untrue. When Michaelis’s testimony at the inquest brought to light Wilson’s suspicions of his wife I thought the whole tale would shortly be served up in racy pasquinade—but Catherine, who might have said anything, didn’t say a word. She showed a surprising amount of character about it too—looked at the coroner with determined eyes under that corrected brow of hers, and swore that her sister had never seen Gatsby, that her sister was completely happy with her husband, that her sister had been into no mischief whatever. She convinced herself of it, and cried into her handkerchief, as if the very suggestion was more than she could endure. So Wilson was reduced to a man “deranged by grief” in order that the case might remain in its simplest form. And it rested there.
But all this part of it seemed remote and unessential. I found myself on Gatsby’s side, and alone. From the moment I telephoned news of the catastrophe to West Egg village, every surmise about him, and every practical question, was referred to me. At first I was surprised and confused; then, as he lay in his house and didn’t move or breathe or speak, hour upon hour, it grew upon me that I was responsible, because no one else was interested—interested, I mean, with that intense personal interest to which everyone has some vague right at the end.
I called up Daisy half an hour after we found him, called her instinctively and without hesitation. But she and Tom had gone away early that afternoon, and taken baggage with them.
“Left no address?”
“No.”
“Say when they’d be back?”
“No.”
“Any idea where they are? How I could reach them?”
“I don’t know. Can’t say.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: After two years I remember the rest of that day, and that night and the next day, only as an endless drill of police and photographers and newspaper men in and out of Gatsby’s front door. The police, with their thick, dark uniforms, moved about hurriedly, taking notes and questioning witnesses. Reporters jostled each other, shouting into their microphones, eager for the latest scoop. The crowd outside was a mixture of curious onlookers and mourners, all trying to catch a glimpse of the tragedy. A detective, with a stern face and a voice that cut through the chaos, declared Wilson a 'madman,' which set the tone for the sensationalized stories that soon appeared in the papers. Catherine, pale and trembling, sat at the inquest, claiming Myrtle was happy with Wilson and had never known Gatsby, painting a picture of a tragic love triangle turned deadly. Her performance was convincing; she appeared to mourn her sister deeply, her tears genuine or not, it was hard to tell. Nick, standing apart from the crowd, felt a strange kinship with Gatsby, the man who had been so full of hope and dreams, now lying dead. He was the only one truly interested in Gatsby’s story, and all inquiries about him were directed to Nick, as if he had become the keeper of Gatsby’s memory. Instinctively, Nick reached for his phone and called Daisy, only to find she and Tom had already left town, their whereabouts unknown, their departure abrupt. The Buchanans’ swift exit left Nick feeling more isolated, the weight of Gatsby’s death pressing heavily on him as he watched the chaos unfold around him.

events.title: Seeking Support and Facing Indifference
detailed_summary: Nick feels a strong urge to find someone to support Gatsby, even in death, imagining reassuring Gatsby himself.
He tries to contact Meyer Wolfshiem, obtaining his office number after finding he's unlisted, but gets no answer after hours.
Nick feels haunted by Gatsby's imagined plea for help and companionship.
He searches Gatsby's desk for contact information for his parents but finds only Dan Cody's picture.
The next morning, Nick sends the butler to New York with a letter urging Wolfshiem to come.
Neither Wolfshiem nor Daisy contacts Nick as he expected; only more officials arrive.
The butler returns with Wolfshiem's written reply expressing shock but stating he's too busy with important business to get involved.
Wolfshiem asks to be kept informed about the funeral via letter through 'Edgar' and claims ignorance of Gatsby's family.
Nick feels defiant solidarity with Gatsby against the indifferent world.
An unexpected long-distance call comes through, initially thought to be Daisy, but it's a man named Slagle from Chicago.
Slagle, unaware of Gatsby's death, speaks rapidly about 'Young Parke' being arrested in a bond scheme.
Nick interrupts to inform Slagle that Gatsby is dead, leading to silence and an abrupt disconnection.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I wanted to get somebody for him.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: There was a long silence on the other end of the wire, followed by an exclamation… then a quick squawk as the connection was broken.

events.text_segment:
I wanted to get somebody for him. I wanted to go into the room where he lay and reassure him: “I’ll get somebody for you, Gatsby. Don’t worry. Just trust me and I’ll get somebody for you—”
Meyer Wolfshiem’s name wasn’t in the phone book. The butler gave me his office address on Broadway, and I called Information, but by the time I had the number it was long after five, and no one answered the phone.
“Will you ring again?”
“I’ve rung three times.”
“It’s very important.”
“Sorry. I’m afraid no one’s there.”
I went back to the drawing-room and thought for an instant that they were chance visitors, all these official people who suddenly filled it. But, though they drew back the sheet and looked at Gatsby with shocked eyes, his protest continued in my brain:
“Look here, old sport, you’ve got to get somebody for me. You’ve got to try hard. I can’t go through this alone.”
Someone started to ask me questions, but I broke away and going upstairs looked hastily through the unlocked parts of his desk—he’d never told me definitely that his parents were dead. But there was nothing—only the picture of Dan Cody, a token of forgotten violence, staring down from the wall.
Next morning I sent the butler to New York with a letter to Wolfshiem, which asked for information and urged him to come out on the next train. That request seemed superfluous when I wrote it. I was sure he’d start when he saw the newspapers, just as I was sure there’d be a wire from Daisy before noon—but neither a wire nor Mr. Wolfshiem arrived; no one arrived except more police and photographers and newspaper men. When the butler brought back Wolfshiem’s answer I began to have a feeling of defiance, of scornful solidarity between Gatsby and me against them all.
Dear Mr. Carraway. This has been one of the most terrible shocks of my life to me I hardly can believe it that it is true at all. Such a mad act as that man did should make us all think. I cannot come down now as I am tied up in some very important business and cannot get mixed up in this thing now. If there is anything I can do a little later let me know in a letter by Edgar. I hardly know where I am when I hear about a thing like this and am completely knocked down and out.
Yours truly
Meyer Wolfshiem
and then hasty addenda beneath:
Let me know about the funeral etc do not know his family at all.
When the phone rang that afternoon and Long Distance said Chicago was calling I thought this would be Daisy at last. But the connection came through as a man’s voice, very thin and far away.
“This is Slagle speaking…”
“Yes?” The name was unfamiliar.
“Hell of a note, isn’t it? Get my wire?”
“There haven’t been any wires.”
“Young Parke’s in trouble,” he said rapidly. “They picked him up when he handed the bonds over the counter. They got a circular from New York giving ’em the numbers just five minutes before. What d’you know about that, hey? You never can tell in these hick towns—”
“Hello!” I interrupted breathlessly. “Look here—this isn’t Mr. Gatsby. Mr. Gatsby’s dead.”
There was a long silence on the other end of the wire, followed by an exclamation… then a quick squawk as the connection was broken.

I wanted to get somebody for him, someone who could understand the depths of his loneliness and the silent despair that often clouded his eyes. It was a task that seemed simple on the surface but was layered with complexities beneath. I thought about the kind of person who could bring a spark back into his life, someone who could listen without judgment and offer companionship without expectation.

In the world we inhabited, where appearances often masked the truth, finding such a person was no small feat. I considered the possibilities—perhaps a friend from his past, someone who knew him before the world had worn him down, or maybe a new acquaintance who could see beyond the veneer of wealth and status.

As I pondered this, I remembered the nights he would sit alone, staring out over the water, lost in thoughts that no one dared to intrude upon. It was during these moments that I realized the importance of genuine connection, something that money or social standing could never buy. I wanted to find someone who could offer him that, someone who could remind him of the simpler joys and the importance of human connection.

The challenge was to find someone who was sincere, untainted by the superficiality that often pervaded our social circles. I thought about the people I knew—those who had no interest in wealth or status, but who valued honesty and kindness. Perhaps one of them could be the person to bridge the gap between his loneliness and the world outside.

I also considered the possibility of introducing him to someone new, someone who might see the world differently and bring a fresh perspective into his life. It was a gamble, but sometimes taking risks was necessary to forge genuine relationships. I hoped that by doing so, I could help him find a sense of belonging, a feeling that had eluded him for so long.

In the end, I knew that the most important thing was sincerity. Any attempt to bring someone into his life had to be genuine, rooted in understanding and compassion. It was not about filling a void with just anyone, but about finding the right person—someone who could truly connect with him on a deeper level.

As I made my plans, I felt a mixture of hope and apprehension. Hope that this could be the beginning of something meaningful, and apprehension about whether I could truly find someone who fit the bill. But above all, I was determined to try, because I believed that everyone deserved a chance at happiness, no matter how lost they might seem.

events.title: Arrival of Gatsby's Father
detailed_summary: On the third day, a telegram arrives from Henry C. Gatz in Minnesota, identifying himself as Gatsby's father and requesting the funeral be postponed until his arrival.
Mr. Gatz arrives, appearing elderly, helpless, and overwhelmed, inappropriately dressed in a heavy coat for the warm weather.
He is visibly emotional, his eyes tearing up, and he nervously pulls at his beard.
Nick takes him inside, offering food and drink, but Mr. Gatz is too distraught to eat or drink steadily.
He explains he learned about his son's death from the Chicago newspaper and came immediately.
Mr. Gatz refers to Wilson as a 'madman'.
Nick leads Mr. Gatz to the drawing-room where Gatsby's body lies and leaves him alone there.
After some time, Mr. Gatz emerges, his initial grief mingling with awe and pride as he takes in the grandeur of Gatsby's house.
Nick helps him upstairs to a bedroom.
Mr. Gatz confirms his name is Gatz, not Gatsby.
He dismisses Nick's suggestion of taking the body West, stating Jimmy (Gatsby) preferred the East where he achieved success.
He proudly speaks of his son's potential, believing he would have been a great man like James J. Hill and contributed significantly to the country.
Overcome with emotion and exhaustion, Mr. Gatz falls asleep almost instantly.

events.text_segment:
I think it was on the third day that a telegram signed Henry C. Gatz arrived from a town in Minnesota. It said only that the sender was leaving immediately and to postpone the funeral until he came.
It was Gatsby’s father, a solemn old man, very helpless and dismayed, bundled up in a long cheap ulster against the warm September day. His eyes leaked continuously with excitement, and when I took the bag and umbrella from his hands he began to pull so incessantly at his sparse grey beard that I had difficulty in getting off his coat. He was on the point of collapse, so I took him into the music-room and made him sit down while I sent for something to eat. But he wouldn’t eat, and the glass of milk spilled from his trembling hand.
“I saw it in the Chicago newspaper,” he said. “It was all in the Chicago newspaper. I started right away.”
“I didn’t know how to reach you.”
His eyes, seeing nothing, moved ceaselessly about the room.
“It was a madman,” he said. “He must have been mad.”
“Wouldn’t you like some coffee?” I urged him.
“I don’t want anything. I’m all right now, Mr.—”
“Carraway.”
“Well, I’m all right now. Where have they got Jimmy?”
I took him into the drawing-room, where his son lay, and left him there. Some little boys had come up on the steps and were looking into the hall; when I told them who had arrived, they went reluctantly away.
After a little while Mr. Gatz opened the door and came out, his mouth ajar, his face flushed slightly, his eyes leaking isolated and unpunctual tears. He had reached an age where death no longer has the quality of ghastly surprise, and when he looked around him now for the first time and saw the height and splendour of the hall and the great rooms opening out from it into other rooms, his grief began to be mixed with an awed pride. I helped him to a bedroom upstairs; while he took off his coat and vest I told him that all arrangements had been deferred until he came.
“I didn’t know what you’d want, Mr. Gatsby—”
“Gatz is my name.”
“—Mr. Gatz. I thought you might want to take the body West.”
He shook his head.
“Jimmy always liked it better down East. He rose up to his position in the East. Were you a friend of my boy’s, Mr.—?”
“We were close friends.”
“He had a big future before him, you know. He was only a young man, but he had a lot of brain power here.”
He touched his head impressively, and I nodded.
“If he’d of lived, he’d of been a great man. A man like James J. Hill. He’d of helped build up the country.”
“That’s true,” I said, uncomfortably.
He fumbled at the embroidered coverlet, trying to take it from the bed, and lay down stiffly—was instantly asleep.

Gatz, a name that echoed with the weight of family history and humble beginnings, had sent word that he was coming to West Egg. Gatsby, who had meticulously crafted his persona and amassed his wealth in pursuit of a dream, now faced the reality of his origins. As the days passed, the anticipation grew among those who knew him, and even among the curious outsiders who had only glimpsed the mysterious figure behind the grand mansion.

When Henry C. Gatz finally arrived, he was a stark contrast to the glamorous world Gatsby inhabited. Dressed plainly, with a weathered face that bore the marks of hard work and years of toil, he carried with him a sense of sincerity and nostalgia. The reunion between father and son was poignant; Gatsby, whose real name was James Gatz, had long concealed his humble beginnings, but now, standing face to face with his father, he was reminded of the roots he had tried to forget.

Henry C. Gatz brought with him a collection of old photographs and a battered leather-bound book, which he eagerly showed Gatsby. The photographs depicted a young James Gatz, full of hope and ambition, standing beside a modest farm in North Dakota. The book was a diary, filled with entries that chronicled the dreams and aspirations of a young man eager to escape the confines of his small town.

As they sat together, Henry C. Gatz spoke of the past with pride and a touch of sadness. He reminisced about the days when Gatsby, then James, had been a diligent boy, full of potential. He expressed his admiration for the man Gatsby had become, despite the distance and the years that had separated them. Gatsby listened intently, a mixture of emotions swirling within him—regret, nostalgia, and a renewed sense of identity.

The visit was a turning point for Gatsby. It forced him to confront the reality of his origins and the sacrifices he had made to forge his new identity. Yet, it also reaffirmed his relentless pursuit of the American Dream—the dream of success, love, and acceptance. As Henry C. Gatz prepared to leave, he looked at Gatsby with a proud smile, knowing that his son had achieved more than he ever could have imagined.

In the days that followed, Gatsby’s demeanor seemed to shift subtly. He was more contemplative, perhaps more aware of the fragile line between illusion and reality. The revelation of his past did not diminish his dreams but added a new layer of depth to his aspirations. He understood that his journey was not just about wealth or status but also about reconciling the man he was with the man he longed to become.

events.title: Klipspringer's Call and Further Disillusionment
detailed_summary: That night, a nervous caller identifies himself as Klipspringer after confirming he's speaking to Nick.
Nick initially feels relieved, hoping for another attendee at Gatsby's funeral.
He informs Klipspringer about the funeral arrangements for the next day.
Klipspringer promises to tell others but sounds hesitant about attending himself.
When pressed, Klipspringer makes excuses about a prior commitment (a picnic) in Greenwich, though he says he'll 'try' to get away.
Nick reacts with disbelief ('Huh!').
Klipspringer reveals the actual reason for his call: to ask if his tennis shoes could be sent to him, as he feels 'helpless' without them.
Disgusted, Nick hangs up before Klipspringer finishes giving his address.
Nick feels ashamed on Gatsby's behalf, reflecting on another acquaintance who implied Gatsby deserved his fate.

events.text_segment:
That night an obviously frightened person called up, and demanded to know who I was before he would give his name.
“This is Mr. Carraway,” I said.
“Oh!” He sounded relieved. “This is Klipspringer.”
I was relieved too, for that seemed to promise another friend at Gatsby’s grave. I didn’t want it to be in the papers and draw a sightseeing crowd, so I’d been calling up a few people myself. They were hard to find.
“The funeral’s tomorrow,” I said. “Three o’clock, here at the house. I wish you’d tell anybody who’d be interested.”
“Oh, I will,” he broke out hastily. “Of course I’m not likely to see anybody, but if I do.”
His tone made me suspicious.
“Of course you’ll be there yourself.”
“Well, I’ll certainly try. What I called up about is—”
“Wait a minute,” I interrupted. “How about saying you’ll come?”
“Well, the fact is—the truth of the matter is that I’m staying with some people up here in Greenwich, and they rather expect me to be with them tomorrow. In fact, there’s a sort of picnic or something. Of course I’ll do my best to get away.”
I ejaculated an unrestrained “Huh!” and he must have heard me, for he went on nervously:
“What I called up about was a pair of shoes I left there. I wonder if it’d be too much trouble to have the butler send them on. You see, they’re tennis shoes, and I’m sort of helpless without them. My address is care of B. F.—”
I didn’t hear the rest of the name, because I hung up the receiver.
After that I felt a certain shame for Gatsby—one gentleman to whom I telephoned implied that he had got what he deserved. However, that was my fault, for he was one of those who used to sneer most bitterly at Gatsby on the courage of Gatsby’s liquor, and I should have known better than to call him.

events.title: Confronting Meyer Wolfshiem
detailed_summary: On the morning of the funeral, Nick goes to New York to see Meyer Wolfshiem personally.
He finds Wolfshiem's office, marked 'The Swastika Holding Company'.
Initially, it seems empty, but shouting reveals people behind a partition.
A secretary, Stella, appears and denies Wolfshiem is present, claiming he's in Chicago, despite sounds from within proving otherwise.
Nick insists on seeing Wolfshiem, mentioning Gatsby.
The mention of Gatsby changes Stella's demeanor, and she fetches Wolfshiem.
Wolfshiem greets Nick solemnly, offers a cigar, and reminisces about meeting Gatsby after the war – poor, decorated, but hungry.
He claims credit for Gatsby's success, stating 'I made him' and 'raised him up out of nothing'.
Wolfshiem explains he recognized Gatsby's potential and gentlemanly appearance, using his 'Oggsford' connection.
He boasts of their close association.
Nick asks Wolfshiem to attend the funeral as Gatsby's closest friend.
Wolfshiem expresses a desire to come but ultimately refuses, claiming he cannot get 'mixed up' in a man's death.
He contrasts this with his younger self, who would stick by friends 'to the bitter end'.
Seeing Wolfshiem's determination, Nick prepares to leave.
Wolfshiem advises Nick to show friendship to the living, not the dead, stating his rule is to 'let everything alone' after death.

events.text_segment:
The morning of the funeral I went up to New York to see Meyer Wolfshiem; I couldn’t seem to reach him any other way. The door that I pushed open, on the advice of an elevator boy, was marked “The Swastika Holding Company,” and at first there didn’t seem to be anyone inside. But when I’d shouted “hello” several times in vain, an argument broke out behind a partition, and presently a lovely Jewess appeared at an interior door and scrutinized me with black hostile eyes.
“Nobody’s in,” she said. “Mr. Wolfshiem’s gone to Chicago.”
The first part of this was obviously untrue, for someone had begun to whistle “The Rosary,” tunelessly, inside.
“Please say that Mr. Carraway wants to see him.”
“I can’t get him back from Chicago, can I?”
At this moment a voice, unmistakably Wolfshiem’s, called “Stella!” from the other side of the door.
“Leave your name on the desk,” she said quickly. “I’ll give it to him when he gets back.”
“But I know he’s there.”
She took a step toward me and began to slide her hands indignantly up and down her hips.
“You young men think you can force your way in here any time,” she scolded. “We’re getting sickantired of it. When I say he’s in Chicago, he’s in Chicago.”
I mentioned Gatsby.
“Oh-h!” She looked at me over again. “Will you just—What was your name?”
She vanished. In a moment Meyer Wolfshiem stood solemnly in the doorway, holding out both hands. He drew me into his office, remarking in a reverent voice that it was a sad time for all of us, and offered me a cigar.
“My memory goes back to when first I met him,” he said. “A young major just out of the army and covered over with medals he got in the war. He was so hard up he had to keep on wearing his uniform because he couldn’t buy some regular clothes. First time I saw him was when he came into Winebrenner’s poolroom at Forty-third Street and asked for a job. He hadn’t eat anything for a couple of days. ‘Come on have some lunch with me,’ I said. He ate more than four dollars’ worth of food in half an hour.”
“Did you start him in business?” I inquired.
“Start him! I made him.”
“Oh.”
“I raised him up out of nothing, right out of the gutter. I saw right away he was a fine-appearing, gentlemanly young man, and when he told me he was at Oggsford I knew I could use him good. I got him to join the American Legion and he used to stand high there. Right off he did some work for a client of mine up to Albany. We were so thick like that in everything”—he held up two bulbous fingers—“always together.”
I wondered if this partnership had included the World’s Series transaction in 1919.
“Now he’s dead,” I said after a moment. “You were his closest friend, so I know you’ll want to come to his funeral this afternoon.”
“I’d like to come.”
“Well, come then.”
The hair in his nostrils quivered slightly, and as he shook his head his eyes filled with tears.
“I can’t do it—I can’t get mixed up in it,” he said.
“There’s nothing to get mixed up in. It’s all over now.”
“When a man gets killed I never like to get mixed up in it in any way. I keep out. When I was a young man it was different—if a friend of mine died, no matter how, I stuck with them to the end. You may think that’s sentimental, but I mean it—to the bitter end.”
I saw that for some reason of his own he was determined not to come, so I stood up.
“Are you a college man?” he inquired suddenly.
For a moment I thought he was going to suggest a “gonnegtion,” but he only nodded and shook my hand.
“Let us learn to show our friendship for a man when he is alive and not after he is dead,” he suggested. “After that my own rule is to let everything alone.”

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
The morning of the funeral I went up to New York to see Meyer Wolfshiem; I couldn’t seem to reach him any other way. I called him several times, but there was no answer, so I decided to go directly. I found his office, marked 'The Swastika Holding Company,' and as I approached, I saw that the door was slightly ajar. I pushed it open and called out, but there was no response. Suddenly, I heard voices behind a partition, and a woman’s voice, sharp and indignant, demanded to know who I was and what I wanted.

I stepped inside and saw a secretary, a young woman with a scrutinizing gaze, sitting at a desk. She looked at me with suspicion and asked for my name. I told her I was a friend of Gatsby’s and wanted to see Wolfshiem. She hesitated, then insisted that Wolfshiem was not there, claiming he was in Chicago, though I could hear sounds from within that suggested otherwise.

She grew more indignant, complaining about young men trying to force their way in and insisting she couldn’t let anyone see him without an appointment. I pressed her, mentioning Gatsby again, and she finally looked annoyed and disappeared behind a door. After a moment, she returned and, without a word, left the room, closing the door behind her.

Then, suddenly, the door swung open, and Wolfshiem appeared. He held out both hands, drawing me into his office, and greeted me with a solemn nod. His face was serious, and he looked older than I remembered. He offered me a cigar, which I declined, and then he sat down, gesturing for me to do the same.

He began to speak about Gatsby, reminiscing about their first meeting after the war. He told me Gatsby was poor then, decorated but hungry, and that he met him at a restaurant in New York, where Gatsby ate everything on the table—chicken, bread, fruit, and even the silverware—until he was full. Wolfshiem said he recognized Gatsby’s potential immediately, noting his gentlemanly appearance and his connection to Oggsford. He claimed, 'I made him,' and 'raised him up out of nothing,' emphasizing their close relationship.

He recounted how Gatsby had come to him after the war, seeking help, and how they had worked together, with Wolfshiem boasting of their association, holding up two fingers to illustrate their closeness. I wondered silently about his involvement in past events, but said nothing.

I then asked if he would attend Gatsby’s funeral. He looked away, hesitated, and finally said he would like to come but couldn’t get involved in a man’s death. He explained that he had a rule to 'let everything alone' after death, and that he preferred to keep his distance. He spoke of his younger self, who would have stuck by friends to the bitter end, but now he was older and more cautious.

Seeing his resolve, I prepared to leave. He then looked at me intently and asked about my background, shaking my hand firmly. I told him I was a college man, and he nodded, saying that was good. As I turned to go, he advised me to show friendship to the living, not the dead, and that sometimes the best thing to do was to 'let everything alone' after death.

- Wolfshiem's reminiscence about Gatsby is paraphrased and lacks the original's specific order of events and details, such as the mention of the American Legion and the work in Albany.
- The completion condenses Wolfshiem's refusal to attend the funeral, omitting the emotional cues and the contrast with his younger self, which are more drawn out in the original.
- The final advice about friendship is summarized, missing the lead-up and the context of the handshake and the question about college.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The morning of the funeral I went up to New York to see Meyer Wolfshiem; I couldn’t seem to reach him any other way. The city was bustling, yet beneath the surface, there was a strange stillness, as if everyone was holding their breath. I found Wolfshiem in his office, a small, cluttered room filled with the scent of cigars and old books. He looked up as I entered, his eyes sharp and calculating.

"I hear about Gatsby," he said quietly, leaning back in his chair. "He was a good man, despite what some might say."

I nodded, feeling the weight of the day pressing down on me. "I wanted to see you because I thought you might have known him better than most."

Wolfshiem nodded slowly, his fingers tapping on the desk. "Gatsby was a man of dreams, of hopes that he held onto tightly. He believed in the green light, in the future he imagined for himself."

"Do you think he ever truly found what he was looking for?" I asked.

He hesitated, then said, "Sometimes, I think he did. But more often, I think he was chasing shadows. Still, he was loyal, and he believed in the American Dream, even if it was just a mirage."

The room fell silent for a moment. Outside, the city moved on, indifferent to the tragedy that had unfolded. I looked at Wolfshiem, wondering about the man who had been so close to Gatsby, yet seemed to carry his own secrets.

"Did you know about his past?" I inquired.

He shrugged. "Gatsby was a complex man. He reinvented himself, as many do. His past was a shadow he carried, but it didn't define him. What mattered was who he was now, and what he believed in."

I left his office with a heavy heart, contemplating the illusions and realities that had shaped Gatsby's life. As I stepped back into the bustling streets, I realized that the city, with all its noise and chaos, was a reflection of the dreams and disillusionments that everyone carried within.

events.title: Mr. Gatz's Pride and Gatsby's Boyhood Ambitions
detailed_summary: Nick returns to West Egg amidst darkening skies and drizzle.
He finds Mr. Gatz pacing excitedly, his pride in Gatsby and his possessions growing.
Mr. Gatz eagerly shows Nick a worn photograph of Gatsby's house that Jimmy had sent him, pointing out details.
He recounts Gatsby visiting two years prior and buying him the house he currently lives in.
Mr. Gatz reflects that Gatsby's running away from home was justified by his ambition for a 'big future'.
He emphasizes Gatsby's generosity after achieving success.
Mr. Gatz then reveals an old, ragged copy of 'Hopalong Cassidy' belonging to Gatsby as a boy.
He shows Nick the back flyleaf containing a detailed daily schedule dated September 12, 1906.
The schedule includes time for exercise, study (electricity, elocution, inventions), work, and sports.
Beneath the schedule are 'General Resolves': avoiding wasted time, quitting smoking/chewing, bathing regularly, reading improving material, saving money, and being better to parents.
Mr. Gatz sees the book and its contents as proof of Jimmy's inherent drive to 'get ahead' and improve himself.
He proudly reads the items aloud, expecting Nick to be deeply impressed.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: When I left his office the sky had turned dark and I got back to West Egg in a drizzle.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I think he rather expected me to copy down the list for my own use.

events.text_segment:
When I left his office the sky had turned dark and I got back to West Egg in a drizzle. After changing my clothes I went next door and found Mr. Gatz walking up and down excitedly in the hall. His pride in his son and in his son’s possessions was continually increasing and now he had something to show me.
“Jimmy sent me this picture.” He took out his wallet with trembling fingers. “Look there.”
It was a photograph of the house, cracked in the corners and dirty with many hands. He pointed out every detail to me eagerly. “Look there!” and then sought admiration from my eyes. He had shown it so often that I think it was more real to him now than the house itself.
“Jimmy sent it to me. I think it’s a very pretty picture. It shows up well.”
“Very well. Had you seen him lately?”
“He come out to see me two years ago and bought me the house I live in now. Of course we was broke up when he run off from home, but I see now there was a reason for it. He knew he had a big future in front of him. And ever since he made a success he was very generous with me.”
He seemed reluctant to put away the picture, held it for another minute, lingeringly, before my eyes. Then he returned the wallet and pulled from his pocket a ragged old copy of a book called Hopalong Cassidy.
“Look here, this is a book he had when he was a boy. It just shows you.”
He opened it at the back cover and turned it around for me to see. On the last flyleaf was printed the word schedule, and the date September 12, 1906. And underneath:
Rise from bed	6:00	a.m.
Dumbell exercise and wall-scaling	6:15⁠–⁠6:30	“
Study electricity, etc.	7:15⁠–⁠8:15	“
Work	8:30⁠–⁠4:30	p.m.
Baseball and sports	4:30⁠–⁠5:00	“
Practise elocution, poise and how to attain it	5:00⁠–⁠6:00	“
Study needed inventions	7:00⁠–⁠9:00	“
General Resolves
No wasting time at Shafters or [a name, indecipherable]
No more smokeing or chewing.
Bath every other day
Read one improving book or magazine per week
Save $5.00 [crossed out] $3.00 per week
Be better to parents
“I came across this book by accident,” said the old man. “It just shows you, don’t it?”
“It just shows you.”
“Jimmy was bound to get ahead. He always had some resolves like this or something. Do you notice what he’s got about improving his mind? He was always great for that. He told me I et like a hog once, and I beat him for it.”
He was reluctant to close the book, reading each item aloud and then looking eagerly at me. I think he rather expected me to copy down the list for my own use.

As I drove through the quiet streets, I couldn't shake the feeling of emptiness that had settled over me. It was as if the world had shifted beneath my feet, leaving me to navigate a new, uncertain reality. The drizzle continued to fall, mingling with my thoughts, as I contemplated the fragile nature of happiness and the inevitable decay of dreams. The night was quiet, yet inside me, a storm was brewing, full of questions and unspoken fears. I knew that the path ahead would be fraught with challenges, but I also understood that some truths could never be fully revealed, only hinted at in the shadows of our lives. As I pulled into my driveway, the rain slowed, and a sense of melancholy settled over me, reminding me of the elusive nature of the American Dream and the cost of chasing it.

events.title: The Sparse Funeral
detailed_summary: Shortly before 3 PM, the Lutheran minister arrives for the funeral.
Nick and Mr. Gatz anxiously watch for other mourners, but none arrive.
As time passes, Mr. Gatz becomes increasingly worried, commenting nervously about the rain.
The minister checks his watch repeatedly; Nick persuades him to wait half an hour longer, but it's futile.
Around 5 PM, a small procession of three vehicles (hearse, limousine with Nick, Gatz, and minister, and station wagon with servants and postman) reaches the cemetery in heavy drizzle.
As they enter the cemetery, Nick hears a car stop and sees someone approaching.
It is the 'owl-eyed man' Nick previously met in Gatsby's library.
Owl Eyes, soaked by the rain, wipes his glasses to watch the burial.
Nick momentarily tries to think of Gatsby but finds him distant, only recalling Daisy's silence.
Someone murmurs a blessing for the dead in the rain, and Owl Eyes says 'Amen'.
After the brief ceremony, the attendees quickly return to the cars.
Owl Eyes speaks to Nick at the gate, expressing surprise that no one else came, remarking how hundreds used to attend Gatsby's parties.
He wipes his glasses again and calls Gatsby 'The poor son-of-a-bitch'.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: A little before three the Lutheran minister arrived from Flushing, and I began to look involuntarily out the windows for other cars.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “The poor son-of-a-bitch,” he said.

events.text_segment:
A little before three the Lutheran minister arrived from Flushing, and I began to look involuntarily out the windows for other cars. So did Gatsby’s father. And as the time passed and the servants came in and stood waiting in the hall, his eyes began to blink anxiously, and he spoke of the rain in a worried, uncertain way. The minister glanced several times at his watch, so I took him aside and asked him to wait for half an hour. But it wasn’t any use. Nobody came.
About five o’clock our procession of three cars reached the cemetery and stopped in a thick drizzle beside the gate—first a motor hearse, horribly black and wet, then Mr. Gatz and the minister and me in the limousine, and a little later four or five servants and the postman from West Egg, in Gatsby’s station wagon, all wet to the skin. As we started through the gate into the cemetery I heard a car stop and then the sound of someone splashing after us over the soggy ground. I looked around. It was the man with owl-eyed glasses whom I had found marvelling over Gatsby’s books in the library one night three months before.
I’d never seen him since then. I don’t know how he knew about the funeral, or even his name. The rain poured down his thick glasses, and he took them off and wiped them to see the protecting canvas unrolled from Gatsby’s grave.
I tried to think about Gatsby then for a moment, but he was already too far away, and I could only remember, without resentment, that Daisy hadn’t sent a message or a flower. Dimly I heard someone murmur “Blessed are the dead that the rain falls on,” and then the owl-eyed man said “Amen to that,” in a brave voice.
We straggled down quickly through the rain to the cars. Owl-eyes spoke to me by the gate.
“I couldn’t get to the house,” he remarked.
“Neither could anybody else.”
“Go on!” He started. “Why, my God! they used to go there by the hundreds.”
He took off his glasses and wiped them again, outside and in.
“The poor son-of-a-bitch,” he said.

The day was hot and the air was thick with the scent of summer, a typical New York afternoon. As I watched the street, my eyes kept drifting to the driveway, hoping for a glimpse of the car that was supposed to arrive. The minister, a tall man with a kind face, seemed to sense my impatience and offered a gentle smile. He was here to perform a service, perhaps a funeral or a blessing, but my mind was elsewhere, preoccupied with the events that had led up to this moment.

The house was quiet except for the faint hum of distant city sounds and the occasional rustle of leaves in the breeze. I felt a mixture of anticipation and unease, knowing that whatever was about to happen would mark a turning point. The clock on the wall ticked steadily, each second stretching longer than the last. I kept glancing at the driveway, my eyes searching for the familiar shape of a car, a sign that the moment I had been waiting for was near.

Suddenly, a car appeared at the end of the street, its engine humming softly as it approached. My heart quickened, and I straightened in my seat. The car slowed as it turned into the driveway, and I saw the figure behind the wheel—someone I hadn't seen in a long time. As the vehicle came to a stop, I felt a rush of emotions—hope, anxiety, and a strange sense of relief.

The minister stepped aside as the door opened, and a figure stepped out, tall and composed. It was him. The person I had been waiting for. I took a deep breath, trying to steady myself, as I prepared to face whatever was to come next. The moment was finally here, and I knew that everything was about to change.

events.title: Reflections on East vs. West and Decision to Leave
detailed_summary: Nick recalls vivid memories of returning home to the Midwest from school during Christmas.
He describes the atmosphere at Chicago's Union Station, the goodbyes, and the train journey into the snowy landscape.
He reflects on the feeling of connection to his homeland experienced during those trips.
Nick defines his Midwest not by landscapes but by these youthful returns and the cozy familiarity of home.
He realizes the story he's told is fundamentally about Westerners (himself, Gatsby, Tom, Daisy, Jordan) who were ill-suited to Eastern life.
Even at its most exciting, Nick found the East possessed a 'quality of distortion'.
He envisions West Egg as a grotesque night scene, comparing it to an El Greco painting, symbolizing moral decay and indifference.
After Gatsby's death, the East feels irredeemably haunted and distorted to Nick.
As autumn sets in, he decides to leave the East and return home to the Midwest.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: One of my most vivid memories is of coming back West from prep school and later from college at Christmas time.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: So when the blue smoke of brittle leaves was in the air and the wind blew the wet laundry stiff on the line I decided to come back home.

events.text_segment:
One of my most vivid memories is of coming back West from prep school and later from college at Christmas time. Those who went farther than Chicago would gather in the old dim Union Station at six o’clock of a December evening, with a few Chicago friends, already caught up into their own holiday gaieties, to bid them a hasty goodbye. I remember the fur coats of the girls returning from Miss This-or-That’s and the chatter of frozen breath and the hands waving overhead as we caught sight of old acquaintances, and the matchings of invitations: “Are you going to the Ordways’? the Herseys’? the Schultzes’?” and the long green tickets clasped tight in our gloved hands. And last the murky yellow cars of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul railroad looking cheerful as Christmas itself on the tracks beside the gate.
When we pulled out into the winter night and the real snow, our snow, began to stretch out beside us and twinkle against the windows, and the dim lights of small Wisconsin stations moved by, a sharp wild brace came suddenly into the air. We drew in deep breaths of it as we walked back from dinner through the cold vestibules, unutterably aware of our identity with this country for one strange hour, before we melted indistinguishably into it again.
That’s my Middle West—not the wheat or the prairies or the lost Swede towns, but the thrilling returning trains of my youth, and the street lamps and sleigh bells in the frosty dark and the shadows of holly wreaths thrown by lighted windows on the snow. I am part of that, a little solemn with the feel of those long winters, a little complacent from growing up in the Carraway house in a city where dwellings are still called through decades by a family’s name. I see now that this has been a story of the West, after all—Tom and Gatsby, Daisy and Jordan and I, were all Westerners, and perhaps we possessed some deficiency in common which made us subtly unadaptable to Eastern life.
Even when the East excited me most, even when I was most keenly aware of its superiority to the bored, sprawling, swollen towns beyond the Ohio, with their interminable inquisitions which spared only the children and the very old—even then it had always for me a quality of distortion. West Egg, especially, still figures in my more fantastic dreams. I see it as a night scene by El Greco: a hundred houses, at once conventional and grotesque, crouching under a sullen, overhanging sky and a lustreless moon. In the foreground four solemn men in dress suits are walking along the sidewalk with a stretcher on which lies a drunken woman in a white evening dress. Her hand, which dangles over the side, sparkles cold with jewels. Gravely the men turn in at a house—the wrong house. But no one knows the woman’s name, and no one cares.
After Gatsby’s death the East was haunted for me like that, distorted beyond my eyes’ power of correction. So when the blue smoke of brittle leaves was in the air and the wind blew the wet laundry stiff on the line I decided to come back home.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
One of my most vivid memories is of coming back West from prep school and later from college at Christmas time. I remember the great city of Chicago, the Union Station packed with travelers, the farewells, the hurried goodbyes, and the train pulling out into the snowy landscape beyond. As the train moved through the cold, I felt a deep connection to my homeland, a sense of returning to a place that was truly mine. I have always thought of my Midwest not just by its landscapes but by these journeys back to the familiar, the warmth of home, and the youthful anticipation of being there again.

Reflecting on my stories, I realize they are fundamentally about Westerners—Gatsby, Tom, Daisy, Jordan, and myself—who were ill-suited to the East's strange, distorted world. Even at its most exciting, the East seemed to possess a quality of distortion, a kind of moral and spiritual dislocation. I picture West Egg as a grotesque night scene, like an El Greco painting—twisted, elongated, and filled with a sense of decay and indifference.

After Gatsby's death, the East felt irredeemably haunted and distorted to me. The glamour and allure had faded, revealing a landscape of moral decay. As autumn approached, I knew I had to leave this place behind. I decided to return home to the Midwest, to the simplicity and authenticity I longed for, leaving behind the illusions and the distortions of the East.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The journey was always filled with a mixture of anticipation and melancholy. As the train wound its way through the snow-covered landscape, I could see the familiar outlines of the West emerging in the distance—rolling hills, distant mountains, and the sprawling fields that seemed to stretch endlessly. The air was crisp and cold, carrying with it the scent of pine and the faint aroma of woodsmoke from distant chimneys.

Upon arriving home, the atmosphere was tinged with a sense of warmth and comfort. The house, though modest, was alive with the sounds of family—laughter, conversations, and the clatter of dishes. My mother would be bustling in the kitchen, preparing holiday treats, while my father would be reading by the fire, his face illuminated by the flickering flames. The familiar sights and sounds created a sense of belonging that I cherished deeply.

One particular Christmas stands out vividly in my memory. It was the year I had just finished college, and I was returning with a sense of both accomplishment and uncertainty. The snow was falling gently as I stepped off the train, and I was greeted by my family with warm embraces. That evening, we gathered around the fireplace, sharing stories and reminiscing about past holidays. The glow of the fire cast a golden hue over everything, and I felt an overwhelming sense of gratitude.

Later, I would often find myself wandering outside, gazing up at the starry sky. The quiet of the winter night was profound, and I felt a deep connection to the land and to my roots. The stillness was occasionally broken by the distant howl of a coyote or the rustling of the trees in the wind. These moments of solitude allowed me to reflect on my journey—how far I had come and the dreams I held for the future.

Christmas mornings were especially magical. The house would be filled with the aroma of freshly baked bread and cinnamon, and the tree, decorated with handmade ornaments, stood proudly in the corner. We would exchange gifts, each one carefully chosen and wrapped, and share laughter and joy. These simple pleasures created memories that I carry with me to this day.

As I grew older, returning West during the holidays became a tradition that grounded me. It reminded me of where I came from and the values that shaped me. The landscape, the people, and the sense of community all contributed to a feeling of stability and hope. Even amidst the changing world, these moments of returning home remained a constant source of comfort.

Looking back, those Christmas journeys were more than just trips; they were rites of passage, moments of reflection, and celebrations of family and home. They reinforced the importance of roots and the enduring power of tradition. No matter where life took me, the memories of returning West during Christmas time would always hold a special place in my heart, symbolizing a time of innocence, love, and belonging.

events.title: Ending Affairs: Jordan and Tom
detailed_summary: Before leaving, Nick feels compelled to resolve his situation with Jordan Baker.
He meets her and discusses their relationship and its aftermath.
Jordan listens impassively, dressed for golf.
She informs Nick she is engaged to another man, which Nick doubts but accepts.
As Nick gets up to leave, Jordan confronts him, accusing him of being the one who ended things ('threw me over').
She recalls their earlier conversation about bad drivers, implying Nick was another 'bad driver' she encountered and suggesting his proclaimed honesty was a facade.
Nick responds defensively, citing his age (thirty) as being past self-deception.
Feeling angry, regretful, and still somewhat attracted to her, Nick turns away.
Later, Nick encounters Tom Buchanan on Fifth Avenue.
Tom confronts Nick about seeming unwilling to shake his hand.
Nick asks Tom directly what he told George Wilson on the afternoon of the murder.
Tom confesses he told Wilson that Gatsby owned the yellow car.
He justifies this by claiming Wilson was armed, threatening, and forced his way into the house.
Tom asserts Gatsby deserved it for running over Myrtle without stopping.
Nick recognizes he can't argue with Tom's distorted version of events.
Tom laments his own 'suffering', mentioning crying over a box of dog biscuits found in the flat he shared with Myrtle.
Nick concludes that Tom and Daisy are careless people who destroy things and retreat into their wealth, letting others clean up their messes.
He shakes Tom's hand, feeling as if dealing with a child, before Tom enters a jewelry store.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: There was one thing to be done before I left, an awkward, unpleasant thing that perhaps had better have been let alone.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Then he went into the jewellery store to buy a pearl necklace—or perhaps only a pair of cuff buttons—rid of my provincial squeamishness forever.

events.text_segment:
There was one thing to be done before I left, an awkward, unpleasant thing that perhaps had better have been let alone. But I wanted to leave things in order and not just trust that obliging and indifferent sea to sweep my refuse away. I saw Jordan Baker and talked over and around what had happened to us together, and what had happened afterward to me, and she lay perfectly still, listening, in a big chair.
She was dressed to play golf, and I remember thinking she looked like a good illustration, her chin raised a little jauntily, her hair the colour of an autumn leaf, her face the same brown tint as the fingerless glove on her knee. When I had finished she told me without comment that she was engaged to another man. I doubted that, though there were several she could have married at a nod of her head, but I pretended to be surprised. For just a minute I wondered if I wasn’t making a mistake, then I thought it all over again quickly and got up to say goodbye.
“Nevertheless you did throw me over,” said Jordan suddenly. “You threw me over on the telephone. I don’t give a damn about you now, but it was a new experience for me, and I felt a little dizzy for a while.”
We shook hands.
“Oh, and do you remember”—she added—“a conversation we had once about driving a car?”
“Why—not exactly.”
“You said a bad driver was only safe until she met another bad driver? Well, I met another bad driver, didn’t I? I mean it was careless of me to make such a wrong guess. I thought you were rather an honest, straightforward person. I thought it was your secret pride.”
“I’m thirty,” I said. “I’m five years too old to lie to myself and call it honour.”
She didn’t answer. Angry, and half in love with her, and tremendously sorry, I turned away.
One afternoon late in October I saw Tom Buchanan. He was walking ahead of me along Fifth Avenue in his alert, aggressive way, his hands out a little from his body as if to fight off interference, his head moving sharply here and there, adapting itself to his restless eyes. Just as I slowed up to avoid overtaking him he stopped and began frowning into the windows of a jewellery store. Suddenly he saw me and walked back, holding out his hand.
“What’s the matter, Nick? Do you object to shaking hands with me?”
“Yes. You know what I think of you.”
“You’re crazy, Nick,” he said quickly. “Crazy as hell. I don’t know what’s the matter with you.”
“Tom,” I inquired, “what did you say to Wilson that afternoon?”
He stared at me without a word, and I knew I had guessed right about those missing hours. I started to turn away, but he took a step after me and grabbed my arm.
“I told him the truth,” he said. “He came to the door while we were getting ready to leave, and when I sent down word that we weren’t in he tried to force his way upstairs. He was crazy enough to kill me if I hadn’t told him who owned the car. His hand was on a revolver in his pocket every minute he was in the house—” He broke off defiantly. “What if I did tell him? That fellow had it coming to him. He threw dust into your eyes just like he did in Daisy’s, but he was a tough one. He ran over Myrtle like you’d run over a dog and never even stopped his car.”
There was nothing I could say, except the one unutterable fact that it wasn’t true.
“And if you think I didn’t have my share of suffering—look here, when I went to give up that flat and saw that damn box of dog biscuits sitting there on the sideboard, I sat down and cried like a baby. By God it was awful—”
I couldn’t forgive him or like him, but I saw that what he had done was, to him, entirely justified. It was all very careless and confused. They were careless people, Tom and Daisy—they smashed up things and creatures and then retreated back into their money or their vast carelessness, or whatever it was that kept them together, and let other people clean up the mess they had made…
I shook hands with him; it seemed silly not to, for I felt suddenly as though I were talking to a child. Then he went into the jewellery store to buy a pearl necklace—or perhaps only a pair of cuff buttons—rid of my provincial squeamishness forever.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: There was one thing to be done before I left, an awkward, unpleasant thing that perhaps had better have been let alone. I felt I ought to see Jordan Baker and settle things with her, so I went to her apartment. She was dressed for golf, listening impassively as I spoke. She told me she was engaged to another man, which I doubted but accepted. As I got up to leave, she suddenly confronted me, accusing me of being the one who threw her over. She recalled our earlier conversation about bad drivers, implying I was another one, and suggested my honesty was just a facade. I responded defensively, citing my age—thirty—as proof I was past self-deception. Feeling angry, regretful, and still somewhat attracted to her, I turned away. Later, I encountered Tom Buchanan on Fifth Avenue. He approached me, asking why I seemed unwilling to shake his hand. I asked him directly what he told George Wilson about the night of the murder. He admitted he told Wilson that Gatsby owned the yellow car, justifying it by claiming Wilson was armed and threatening, forcing his way into the house. Tom said Gatsby deserved it for running over Myrtle without stopping. I realized I couldn't argue with Tom’s distorted version of events. Tom then lamented his own suffering, mentioning he had cried over a box of dog biscuits found in the flat he shared with Myrtle. I concluded that Tom and Daisy are careless people who destroy things and retreat into their wealth, leaving others to clean up their messes. I shook Tom’s hand, feeling as if I was dealing with a child, before he entered a jewelry store.
